datafield.subfield: The present paper accounts for progress in physics teaching in the sense that a problem, which has been closed to students for being too difficult, is gained for the high school curriculum. This problem is the compound Atwood machine with three bodies. Its introduction into high school classes is based on a recent study on the weighing of an Atwood machine.
Departamento de História e Filosofia das Ciências da Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade de Lisboa - Lisboa - Portugal
Centro Interuniversitário de História das Ciências e da Tecnologia - Universidade de Lisboa - Lisboa - Portugal
We can now speak of the weight of an Atwood machine, which has not been a concept in textbooks
The weight of an Atwood machine, when in motion, is equal to its total tension : #pedaa5e1abib001, equation (, 4: #pedaa5e1aeqn004))
Calculate the acceleration of an Atwood machine, where the bodies have the mass 0.5 kg and weight 4.704 N
Calculate the acceleration and the total tension of an Atwood machine with bodies, whose masses are 0.2 and 0.3 kg
Calculate the acceleration of the latter Atwood machine in an elevator with the upward acceleration of 0.2 ms-2

The weight of the secondary Atwood machine before it is connected with the main one. This corresponds to the total tension of this machine, which students are able to calculate. Indeed, the teacher needs above all to make the link between the two concepts: total tension and the weight of the Atwood machine

The acceleration of the secondary Atwood machine in the non-inertial frame of reference. If students have previously addressed the weight in an elevator issue, they are able to determine the weights of bodies 1 and 2 in an elevator. The teacher only needs to call their attention to the fact that these are the weights to use because these are the weights of the bodies in that frame

This problem reappears in university textbooks. See, for instance (,: #pedaa5e1abib005), Reif (, 1995: #pedaa5e1abib009), Wilson and Buffa (, 1997: #pedaa5e1abib011), Serway and Beichner (, 2006: #pedaa5e1abib010), Greiner (, 2008: #pedaa5e1abib004) and Lüders and Oppen (, 2012: #pedaa5e1abib007)
(,: #pedaa5e1abib008) carried out a similar problem but developed a different solving strategy
González (,: #pedaa5e1abib003) and Jafari Matehkolaee (, 2011: #pedaa5e1abib006) developed a similar strategy, apparently unaware of the previous paper
Coelho R L, Silva P and Borges P F
‘Diagonalization’ of a compound Atwood machine Crossref:
¿Podemos aprender algo nuevo con la máquina de Atwood?

When equal masses don’t balance Phys. Edu. 39 289-93
